title: 112_s341
content:
The Act is titled the "No Contracting with the Enemy Act of 2011" and includes definitions. The Act titled "No Contracting with the Enemy Act of 2011" provides definitions for terms such as "element of the intelligence community," "enemy of the United States," and "executive agency." The Act defines terms such as "Federal Acquisition Regulation" as the regulation maintained under title 41, United States Code, and "Federal contract" as any contract entered into by an executive agency for procurement of property or services. SEC. 3. PROHIBITION ON CONTRACTS WITH ENEMIES. The Federal Acquisition Regulatory Council must amend the Federal Acquisition Regulation within 60 days of this Act's enactment to prohibit awarding contracts to enemies of the United States. Any contract with an enemy of the United States will be null and void, allowing for immediate termination at no cost to the government. Subcontracts under federal contracts to enemies of the United States are also prohibited. Federal contracts must include a clause prohibiting subcontracting to enemies of the United States. If a prime contractor subcontracts to an enemy, they must terminate the subcontract immediately with no further payment. Failure to do so may result in default on the prime contract. The clause prohibits further payments to subcontractors who pose a threat to national security, with exceptions for intelligence community contracts. The Administrator for Federal Procurement Policy will monitor terminated contracts. Services to add a field to FAPIIS for recording contracts terminated due to connections with enemies of the United States. The Administrator for Federal Procurement Policy will ensure dissemination of regulations to all personnel and contractors. SEC. 4. DETERMINATION OF ENEMY STATUS. The Secretary of Defense, in coordination with the Secretary of State, must establish regulations within 60 days of the enactment of the Act for executive agencies to determine if a party to a contract is an enemy of the United States. The regulations will include processes for verifying information reliability, protecting confidential sources, and documenting the basis for determinations. The regulations must include processes for verifying information reliability, protecting confidential sources, and documenting the basis for determinations. Additionally, there should be a process for retaining such information for possible review under section 5. SEC. 5. DUE PROCESS PROCEDURE.

Any contractor whose contract is voided or terminated under prescribed procedures may utilize procedures under chapter 71 of title 41, United States Code, with the only claim basis being not an enemy of the United States. Regulations will be amended to protect national security when a claim is submitted.

SEC. 6. APPLICABILITY.

This Act and its amendments apply to contracts entered into after the enactment date.
